shortBio.en-US:
I'm Lassiter Gregg, a software engineer, born and initially raised in the Philippines with stents across Europe and the good ole USA. He currently resides in Houston, TX with occasional stints in NYC and Chicago.

I build useful and interesting things to solve problems while applying my past experiences in the marketing & advertising, legal, non-profit, and media industries along the way.

Before, I worked as an integrated producer and marketing consultant in Chicago and NYC with AIGA, Moody Global Ministries, and local small businesses.

longBio.en-US:
__Lassiter Gregg is a multi-disciplinary builder of useful and interesting things. Originally born and initially raised in the Philippines with stents across Europe and the good ole USA. He currently resides in Houston, TX, and NYC.__

Lassiter's journey has been a series of zigs and zags. Ranging from living overseas and everything that entails to dropping out of high school for a year then returning to bust his ass completing high school with almost an associates degree. He eventually ended up at a seminary pursuing life's biggest questions. 

During that time, Lassiter landed in the marketing industry working in it for 5 years and eventually co-founded a small marketing consultancy with two friends. After almost two years of the small business grind, we all realized it was a time for a change and wasn't what we wanted to continue doing. 

Lassiter took the opportunity to move to NYC and continued on as an individual marketing consultant landing clients until he his childhood interest of technology and the Web eventually leading to him joining a year-long software engineering intensive with Bloc and interned with The Futur. Lassiter has no regrets and currently builds software for freelance clients while looking for a permanent home in NYC.

title.en-US: An Introduction to CLIs: A look inside a Junior Software Engineer's CLI Toolbox for other Juniors

body.en-US:
One of the biggest benefits for growing developers is to have a strong toolbox of command line interface (CLI) tools to improve your efficiency. These are the tools that I'm learning or have learned to use and why:

# Git
Where better to start than Git which is arguably is the most important command line tools that a developer can learn outside of an in terminal editor like Vim or Emacs. It allows us to easily incrementally save and share progress on projects via hosted repositories like GitHub and GitLab. You can easily work on new ideas in their own branch before merging your main project ("master branch") with your new idea ("idea branch").

## Scripts and Aliases that I use for Git

### git detail-log
I have an alias called `detail-log` that I use to review my previous commits across my branches. It provides a visually drawn out terminal log of my commits and how they apply to branches. 

This is the alias:
```
[alias]
       detail-log = log --graph --decorate --oneline
```
It's simply doing three things, listing out the visual graph of my branches then aligining my commits in one line rows along those branches and color coding them.

If you want to use this you can simply type `git config --global alias.detail-log log --graph --decorate --oneline` in your command line or open up `~/.gitconfig` with `vi` or `nano` and copy/paste the alias code block above and restart your terminal. Then, next time you type `git detail-log` in a project you should have an easily readable commit log.

title.en-US: Unique Interactions on Polymorphic Self-Relationships in Rails

body.en-US:
While coding the backend for my capstone FamNet, an open sourced closed social network for families, I eventually got to the need to create a way for users to interact with hearts, likes, stars, and etc. on my primary models: Posts, Comments, Comment on Comments, and Recipes. There were a few ways I could do this: 
- I could approach it from a `has_many :X, through: Y` which would create a lot of tables for each interaction type.
- I could approach it from a ...
Or, I could approach it using a polymorphic self-relationship table, and here is why:

Pros

- item

Cons

- item

In my opinon, x outweighs y which lead me to do this.

My journy started with this post in the Ruby on Rails Link Slack:
> Can a polymorphic association be set on itself? Like,  
> ```
> class Interaction < Application Record
>     belongs_to :interaction, polymorphic: true
> end
> ```
> 
> I'm trying to set up an interaction model/controller for likes, dislikes, hearts, and etc for a post, comment, and commentoncomment models/controllers.
> Ideally, I'd like to call something like `@post.interactions` to see the list of interactions or `@post.interaction.heart!` to create a new specific interaction type.
It was also, 10:14 PM at night, so, I searched and searched until I...

metaDescription.en-US: Manually Entered Meta Description Example - Wow very biscit maximum borkdrive pats you are doing me the shock big ol, maximum borkdrive boofers. Very good spot long bois long woofer heckin smol blep, blop doge big ol pupper.

body.en-US:
I wanted something that could have an easy to use headless CMS while being a staticly built site, so I decieded to use [Gatsby](https://Gatsbyjs.com). The primary reason was to allow me the flexability to edit my website's design by detaching the content using [Contentful](https://contentful.com). I used one of the [starters](https://github.com/ryanwiemer/gatsby-starter-gcn) and edited it to fit my personal design choices. 

So far, I've added a second catagory of projects to the original posts. I've adjusted the about section to pull from a specific content type called `person` which I can have as a central repository of my social links, contact info, and a short and long version of my bio. I've also changed or edited most of the visual styling to match components of my favorite portfolios or websites while adding my own interpretation.

This project was my capstone at Bloc where I pursued the problem in my family around communication. I have about 40 family members (and growing!) which often show up at major gatherings with a low-count of about 15 that show up to almost everything. This makes the chain emails often very confusing and difficult to read along; I wanted create a closed private social network (more on why that's a requirement later) to document events as they come up. So, I added an event planner and tracker portion.

The scope expanded as I began to think of other communication problems my family (and likely others face). Family Recipes, they are often documented on a small sheet of paper in a cookbook. That means once their lost or the family memeber who created or documented it passes, it's gone. I wanted to create a way that family recipes could be documented and searchable within the family. So, I added recipes.

I also realized that some family members are very skeptical of privacy on the internet (which is a valid concern in my opinion). I also realized some family members were concerned about "blowing up people's inboxes" with updates via email. This formed a bit of a catch-22 because they were not comfortable enough to share on common social networks or to send out an email for it might be "bothersome". I disagree, so, I added a news feed portion with posts and comments.

I also realized along the privacy train-of-thought that a directory would be helpful because consistantly in chain email's year after year we get comments like "The original didn't get to Jane. I need a good address for her. Please forward to her, someone." So, that was the last main feature to be added for the inital version.

Another nifty feature that I added, was the ability to invite via email however that requires a bit of setup beyond a default deploy. You can view the [FamNet project here](https://github.com/lassiter/FamNet/ "A link to the project in question, FamNet, hosted on a third-party website called GitHub.").

*Any family member's name you've read in this article has been replaced with a pseudonym.*

# So, you want to know my tech stack?

- Primary Library: [React.js](https://reactjs.org?utm_source=lassitergregg.com&utm_medium=colophon)
- Static Site Generator: [Gatsby.js](https://gatsbyjs.org?utm_source=lassitergregg.com&utm_medium=colophon)
- Content Management System: [Contentful](https://contentful.com?utm_source=lassitergregg.com&utm_medium=colophon)
- Hosting: [Netlify](https://netlify.com?utm_source=lassitergregg.com&utm_medium=colophon)

I have made a lot of modifications of [Ryan Wiemer's](https://github.com/ryanwiemer) [GCN](https://github.com/ryanwiemer/gatsby-starter-gcn) Gatsby starter theme from the Gatsby website. I chose his theme since it had Contentful already setup with a blog and pages. There are also a lot of smaller libraries and plugins I use but [styled-components](https://styled-components.com/) is one of my favorites.

# Privacy Statement
I use Segment and feed that data to Google Analytics and FullStory. I collect this information to get metrics of my site's usage and how it is being used. I use FullStory to identify UX issues and bugs. So, if you "rage click" (the universal digital signal of frustration), by click on something several times quickly then I get notified. By your use of my website, you agree to the necessary collection of this data. If you've got concerns, email [privacy@lassitergregg.com](mailto:privacy@lassitergregg.com "Privacy Email for GDPR").

metaDescription.en-US: The tech stack for Lassiter Gregg.
